bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, June 29, 1942

div1.p: Hench informs Kellogg he will not be able to lecture in Philadelphia, as he expects to go on active military duty soon. He discusses the latest Cornwell painting unveiling ceremony. Hench also comments on Pinto's role in the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, June 29, 1942
div1.opener:
June 29, 1942
Mr. George A. Kellogg
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, N. J.
My dear George:
div1.p:
I wish indeed that I could accept your offer to be my
manager in arranging a lecture tour with the Philadelphia Academy
of Medicine but I don't know much about my immediate future. Pre-
sumably I go on active duty July 20 or earlier for some preliminary
training and then to Camp Carson as chief of the medical service.
But maybe the army will change my orders. I understand that is one
of their favorite tricks.

I am glad indeed to hear of your brother's appointment
with the Seattle group. That sounds as if he might be sent abroad.

I too thought that Freddie Rankin was pleased with the
setup. You certainly had a swanky luncheon and I was flattered to be
at such a high-pressure guest table, just “dripping” generals all
around me.

Don't worry much about Pinto. His part gets smaller and
smaller the more I study it. He did have a part and he may have some
information but as I understand it he was transferred from Cuba before
things really got going and certainly doesn't deserve to be in the
painting. He was bitten by one of the preliminary mosquitoes before
they really knew what they were doing and before mosquito bites were
anything other than sort of a joke. When I learn more about my army
setup I will write you.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
